content: The list provides names of independent counsels appointed by the special Division of the Court for Appointing Independent Counsels, along with areas of investigation and results. Cost information is included from audits by the Government Accountability Office or Department of Justice reports. Total Costs of Investigations: 20 independent counsel or special prosecutor investigations have been initiated under the statutory mechanisms originally enacted as part of the Ethics in Government Act of 1978. The most current cost information was derived from GAO audit reports on independent counsel expenditures. The list includes appointed independent counsels and special prosecutors, some of whom are kept confidential. Information on appointments and investigation targets was generally kept confidential unless deemed in the public interest or upon indictment or criminal information return. The total costs of 20 independent counsel or special prosecutor investigations initiated under the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 amount to approximately $228,712,589. The statutory provisions for independent counsels expired in 1999, but the Attorney General can still appoint temporary personnel within the Department of Justice for investigations and prosecutions. The Attorney General of the United States can hire temporary personnel within the Department of Justice for investigations and prosecutions. Regulations for "special counsels" were established in 1999. Various special counsel investigations have incurred significant costs, such as the Whitewater investigation costing $6,073,000 and the Waco incident investigation costing $15,536,793. Patrick Fitzgerald was designated as a Special Counsel in 2003 to investigate an alleged unauthorized disclosure. The Justice Department designated Patrick Fitzgerald as the "Special Counsel" in 2003 to investigate the unauthorized disclosure of a CIA employee's identity. The expenses for the investigation could be paid from the permanent appropriation for Independent Counsels. Out of 20 independent counsel investigations, 12 resulted in no indictments, while 8 investigations led to at least one indictment. Out of 20 independent counsel investigations, 12 resulted in no indictments. Of the 8 investigations that did lead to indictments, 3 did not result in indictments for the principal Government official initially targeted. In 5 investigations where Federal officials were indicted, 3 officials were either acquitted or had their convictions overturned. Only two federal officials named as subjects of the investigations were ultimately convicted or pleaded guilty. Only two federal officials involved in 20 investigations were convicted or pleaded guilty. In the Independent Counsel investigations, Michael Deaver was convicted of perjury and fined, while Secretary Cisneros pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge and was eventually pardoned. Special prosecutors appointed under federal law have included Arthur H. Christy and Gerald J. Gallinghouse. The special prosecutors investigated allegations of cocaine use by high-profile officials, finding insufficient evidence for criminal charges. The investigations cost $182,000, $3,300, and $318,000 respectively. Only two federal officials were convicted or pleaded guilty in 20 investigations. The investigations by special prosecutors looked into various allegations, including false testimony before a grand jury and financial improprieties. Costs ranged from $7,200 to $318,000 for the investigations. One investigation found no basis for criminal charges, while another investigated false testimony to Congress. Alexia Morrison was appointed to investigate allegations of false testimony by Theodore B. Olson to Congress regarding the EPA "superfund" inquiry. The final report found insufficient evidence of false statements or obstruction of justice. The investigation cost $2,141,000. Whitney North Seymour Jr. investigated Michael K. Deaver for post-employment conflict of interest violations, resulting in Deaver's conviction for perjury and a fine of $100,000. The independent counsel's jurisdiction was expanded multiple times to investigate allegations related to the misuse of FBI files, false statements by White House Counsel Bernard Nussbaum, and allegations of subornation of perjury and obstruction of justice involving Monica Lewinsky. Hubbell on June 30, 1999 signaled the conclusion of the "Whitewater aspect" of the Clintons' investigation. Independent Counsel Ray confirmed on September 20, 2000, that there was insufficient evidence to prove criminal involvement by President or Mrs. Clinton in the Whitewater matter. On June 22, 2000, Independent Counsel Ray announced no criminal indictments for White House aide David Watkins or First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton regarding the White House travel office. The report released on October 18, 2000, found insufficient evidence for criminal conduct. On January 19, 2001, Independent Counsel Ray declined prosecution in the Monica Lewinsky and Paula Jones-deposition matter. President Clinton admitted to giving evasive answers in the Jones civil suit deposition and agreed to a five-year law license suspension and a $25,000 fine. The cost of Independent Counsels' investigations totaled $73,597,345. Donald C. Smaltz was appointed on September 9, 1994, to investigate potential criminal conduct involving gifts received by Secretary of Agriculture Mike Espy. The investigations resulted in guilty pleas, fines, and settlements from various individuals and organizations. Several settlements and guilty pleas were made in relation to a bank loan, campaign contributions, conflict of interest civil suits, and gratuities provided to Secretary Espy and his brother. Companies like Smith Barney Inc., Robert Mondavi Corporation, and Tysons Foods Inc. were involved in these cases. Additionally, jury convictions were obtained against Sun-Diamond Growers of California for gratuities and contributions to Secretary Espy. Other individuals were also convicted for money laundering related to campaign contributions. Several individuals were convicted in relation to money laundering and providing gifts to Secretary Espy and his brother. Convictions included John Hemmingson, Alverez Ferrouillet Jr., Ronald H. Blackley, and Jack L. Williams. Richard Douglas' conviction was set aside, and he later pleaded guilty to false statements. Archibald R. Linda Jones pleaded guilty to multiple felony counts related to fraud. Cisneros pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge and was fined. Cisneros and Jones were pardoned by President Clinton in 2001.
